issues.title: Which key should be the authority for evidence from DICE/SPDM
issues.author: andrew-draper
issues.body:
Which key should be put into the authority entry of DICE/SPDM generated evidence?

It needs to be something which the verifier can match against, so it must be a global key rather than a device specific key.

I suggest that the certificate chain root key authorising the DICE/SPDM evidence is used for this. If there are multiple certificate chains available then all root keys 

It might be worth adding a section describing this.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The verifier matching rule is based on authorized-by condition. It can be any key. 
The key that generated the signature over the digest of the claims should be the key that is in the authority field in the ECT. Note that in the SPDM case, the slot contains the full cert chain. The $crypto-key-type-choice varients that support the full chain might be advised? The authorized-by matching should follow the same convention. 

Note that the cert chain will include the device ID cert which is the global identity hence the cert chain is globally unique.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
One way to address the use case is to populate the ECT authority field with all of the signers in the cert chain that signed the evidence. This would allow an authorized-by condition to be met for long-term authorities (aka Root CA / DeviceID) for evidence that was signed by SPDM/DICE alias keys. 

The matching language in CoRIM doesn't need to change.

The processing / transformation section for populating authority would need to describe walking the cert path for the claims added to the ECT and adding a $crypto-key-type-choice value for each cert in the path. The form of $crypto-key-type-choice used should be consistent to avoid confusion when trying to author authorized-by conditions. Maybe a key thumbprint for space considerations but this may depend on a method for computing the thumbprint (I think CoRIM has an issue for doing this).

comments.author: andrew-draper
comments.body:
I note that the TCG DICE Concise Evidence spec contains this text:

> The authorized-by entry contains the public key identifier from a root or intermediate certificate in the certification
> path of the certificate that issues the DeviceID Key[3]
> 
> [3] Note that the DeviceID Key and keys derived from subsequent DICE layers are device specific, so there is no point in including
> these keys in the authorized-by entry.

I think text adding the keys required in the TCG DICE spec, and adding additional keys, is also compatible with this text.

Adding thumbprints is a good idea for algorithms with large public keys, but that is not directly compatible with the text above I think.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
The CoRIM team determined that authorized-by in CoRIM statements should only apply to condition processing. The TCG spec has an additional semantic (which appears to affect corroboration behavior). Note that CoRIM says 

> "If the ECTs match except for authority, the rv addition ECT authority is added to the ACS ECT authority."

 However, once corroboration is finalized, the original semantics of copying the direct signer of the evidence artifact into the ECT authority field isn't undone by the TCG spec. The TCG spec just defines criteria for accepting the RV artifact(s) not what the ending ECT should look like.

This spec needs to extend/modify the corroboration logic to include checking that the RV signer. 

If the evidence (without authorized-by) directs the cert path keys be included in ECT authority. Then it is reasonable for CoRIM corroboration algorithm to say that: "...the ECTs match if the Evidence ECT authority overlaps (at least by one entry) the RVP authority". 

The missing CoRIM peices needed to support `authorized-by` in Evidence include (a) some place in the ECT to put the delegate RVP authorities. It doesn't make sense to put them in the ECT.`authority` because the delegate RVP didn't sign any evidence. (b) the corroboration logic would need to check the rv.`authority` against the ECT.`delegate-rvp-authority` before concluding that corroboration is valid.

Without making modifications (a) and (b) to CoRIM. I don't see how the TCG concise-evidence authorized-by processing can be achieved. Maybe this spec should document the dependeny but in a non-normative way? Making it normative here would create a scenario for competing specs. It would fall back to the TCG  (or for a vendor profile) to document an alternative behavior IMO.

comments.author: andrew-draper
comments.body: Closed by PR #8

issues.title: Need text describing how instance field is used to separate evidence from multiple attesters
issues.author: andrew-draper
issues.body:
If there are multiple attesters then the Verifier needs a way to separate evidence from them.

The instance field should be filled in with a value derived from the deviceid key to ensure that evidence from each verifier is kept separate.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
If the evidence authority uses a $crypto-key-type-choice that is a cert chain, then the chain will contain the deviceID cert making the authority globally unique. 

However, there is a different issue you're describing (I think) which is how does the Attester uniquely identify itself to the Verifier. There are two parts to the attester-verifier session. Authentication (which should use the deviceID key) and evidence collection which should use whatever attestation keys are most appropriate for the evidence that is reported. It's best to think of these as different keys. 

Note there is a thread on RATS which is arguing for these keys being mandatorily separate as one of the researchers has identified this as a potential security flaw.

The way corim can express the identity of the attester is using instance-id in environment-map where the ID value references the deviceID key. This could be done using the DeviceID directly, or some variant of the $crypto-key-type-choice that includes the DeviceID key. The identity of the device could be one of the claims asserted as part of connection establishment (maybe the DeviceID cert should have a bit of evidence that makes this claim)? Remember when we discussed whether to use some of the cert fields as evidence but decided not to? The consequence of that decision is the identity of device needs to be repeated in the DiceTcbInfo fields for the instance-id claim to be tied to the deviceID. 

The DiceTcbInfo.type field is an OCTET STRING: "type – a machine readable description of the measurement." 

For this to match a reference value environment-map.instance-id.$crypto-key-type-choice. It (OCTET STRING) needs to start with a CBOR tag. (Actually all measurement-map values start with a CBOR tag). But using $crypto-key-type-choice allows the devid cert to be used as a way to link the deviceID cert to the device and for any attestation key in the same device to be linked to the deviceID. 

Note: If the deviceID cert contains only the DiceTcbInfo.`type` value. The reference value needs to be able to match this evidence. Since the external representation of Ref-Val triple makes measurement-map mandatory, there needs to be a measurement also. In this particular case, it makes sense to repeat the DeviceID key in the measurement-values-map.$crypto-key-type-choice. We can document it this way this convention to avoid having to make a pedestrian change to DiceTcbInfo that puts the $crypto-key-type-choice value in there twice.

Note: The $crypto-key-type-choice should probably not be a cert or cert-path form since the inclusion of the digest of the cert or path will affect the signature over the cert which is circular.

The internal representation doesn't mandate the existence of `element-list` (aka measurement-map) hence DiceTcbInfo.type could exists in an internal representation that populated only the environment. Hence, the duplicated value in measurement-values-map could be deleted for internal representation.

Nevertheless, the matching rules for evidence given instance-id.$crypto-key-type-choice with reference value having both instance-id.$crypto-key-type-choice and element-list.element-claims.$crypto-key-type-choice (where both values are the same) should still not trigger a processing error. 

This will result in the Verifier being able to disambiguate Attesters based on the DeviceID credential, but not introduce some irregularity that requires the Verifier to start using certificate fields as if they were intended as Evidence.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
More context:
There are 3 ways to add novel environments to an ACS using corim schemas. 
(a) Evidence - Verifiers accepts it without logical conditions.
(b) Conditional Endorsement - Verifier accepts it if the condition matches.
(c) Membership triple - Verifier accepts it if the Endorser (signer) is in the TA list.

RATS has made hand wavy observations that certificates are a form of endorsement. Any information in a certificate could in theory be considered to be Endorsement claims. But there isn't a discipline for how to map X.509 v3 fields into an ACS.

In (a), a device ID cert could contain attestatation information (e.g., DiceTcbInfo). But since the signer is the mfg'r, not an Attesting Env, the claims are actually Endorsements. Typically, Device ID certs are embedded in the Attester and hence are often size optimized. Adding an `instance-id` in this way may be mixed for practical reasons.

In (b), there's no real way to add an instance-id using conditions that are based on class attributes since ever member of the class would end up with the same instance identifier. Unless, there are special rules Verifiers follow.

In (c), the Verifier searches the certificate/path as the matching criteria. The domain-type could be extended to include $crypto-key-type-choice which includes matching on subject public key / key thumbprint. Note: matching on UUID as device instance id is already supported. This can then result in the addition of an ACS entry for an environment-map.instance-id. If the instance ID is in the cert used to authenticate to the Verifier, then the link between Attester-Verifier session and the ACS can be pinned down. Subsequently, any conditional endorsement that is specific to an instance of the Attester can be expressed in terms of the Attester's instance-id without needing special processing rules expressed as prose in a spec or profile.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
@nedmsmith I agree with mostly what is said here. In addition to what is stated above, in PSA and Arm CCA Case, there is a instance identifier for each PSA/Arm CCA Device which is a `tagged-ue-id-type`  which binds the unique device instance to the Attestation Public key used to verify the Evidence. 

And yes,  Class Identifier should not be used to represent Device Instances, as all the Instance of the same class, share the same class identity.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
And I think, the specification are adequately clear about usage of instances within the environment..

`Instance measurements apply to a specific Attester instance. Environments identified by a class identifier have measurements that are common to the class. Environments identified by an instance identifier have measurements that are specific to that instance`

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> tagged-ue-id-type

How does the tagged-ue-id-type get associated with the device class? Is it in the devID cert or is there an instance RIM that asserts it?

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body: As explained during call, when instance identifier (`a tagged-ue-id-type`) is represented in a CoRIM Reference Value or Evidence in EAT format, it is always used in conjunction with a class identity representing device class, which in this case is class-id: `psa.implementation-id`. The instance is never used in isolation, be it in messages or internally in a Verifier, as uniqueness of identity is always tied to combined `class-identifier`+`instance-identifier`

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> The instance field should be filled in with a value derived from the deviceid key to ensure that evidence from each verifier is kept separate.

Populating the `instance-id` with an identifier (whether its deviceID, tagged-ue-id-type, or other) is a reasonable convention for disambiguating different attesters.

In the case where a host is virtualized (TDX, SEV, CCA), an identifier that is unique to the TEE (vs. the device/platform) would have the appropriate tenant semantics.

Populating both class and instance IDs is possible in concise-evidence and apparently in EAT, but it doesn't appear to be possible in DiceTcbInfo and I'm not sure about SPDM (not using the EAT / Concise-evidence options).

comments.author: andrew-draper
comments.body:
> The DiceTcbInfo.type field is an OCTET STRING: "type – a machine readable description of the measurement."

We have said that `DiceTcbInfo.type` maps to a class identifier, so I don't think that would work as an instance identifier.

One of the properties I think we need for an instance identifier is that the same instance identifier can be extracted from all of the containers which provide Evidence for a Target Environment.

In the SPDM Alias key model (which is used with DICE), the proof of liveness is the signature over the SPDM MEASUREMENTS message. The signing key for the transcript containing this message is provided by one or more certificate chains.

In the Alias key model, the certificate whose public key is the **device identity** is marked with the DICE extKeyUsage identityInit value and the SPDM hardwareIdentity value.

This key works well as an instance identifier, providing that all certificates in the chain, but might not work if the DICE certificate chain contains multiple identities (for example if part of the chain identifies a component which is used as part of the SPDM transport).

To avoid this issue, I suggest that the hardwareIdentity or IdentityInit key nearest the end of the chain (or its hash) should be used as the instance identifier.

comments.author: nedmsmith
comments.body:
> > The DiceTcbInfo.type field is an OCTET STRING: "type – a machine readable description of the measurement."
> 
> We have said that `DiceTcbInfo.type` maps to a class identifier, so I don't think that would work as an instance identifier.

Dice also defines `TcgUeid` extension that asserts a unique enough identifier. It may be reasonable to use this to populate the `instance-id`.

Also, Dice `cmw` extension can be used to put a `concise-evidence` in a certificate where the `instance-id` can be populated directly. 

If a DeviceID cert includes one of these, then it is reasonable for a conditional endorsement to look for an instance-id that is device specific. 

If there is automated behavior that generates instance identifiers in ACSs then that creates a hurdle for entities that want privacy controls where they want ACSs to NOT contain instance information.

comments.author: andrew-draper
comments.body:
Using the DICE UEID extension seems like a good solution to the problem. If noone disagrees then I'll put together a PR which says something like this:

1. When adding evidence from a DICE certificate, if that certificate includes a ueid extension, then set ECT.environment.instance field to the contents of that Ueid extension.
2. When adding evidence from SPDM, if the certificate whose subject key signed the evidence includes a Ueid extension, then set ECT.environment.instance field to the contents of that Ueid extension

This gives the Attester the choice of whether or not to include an instance field in the ECT, which should address privacy issues.

It also handles the case where the certificate chain branches, for example if an entity higher up in a certificate chain issues certificates for multiple entities of the same time lower down the chain (eg a VM manager authorizing chains for multiple VMS). In that case the issuing identity can ensure that it has a different UEID from the entities below it, and that different entities below it have distinct UEIDs.

issues.title: Adding certificates to ACS as part of Evidence processing
issues.author: nedmsmith
issues.body:
Evidence is asserted with the authority of the key that signed it and if Issue #5 is applied, it contains the set of cert path keys as transitively trusted entities. However, there isn't a way to use conditional endorsement to attribute claims to any of the entities in the cert path. For example, a deviceID certificate may have a device type classification, or have key quality properties. 

But for conditional endorsement to be used, there needs to be an ECT entry already in the ACS. A reasonable way to achieve this is for the Evidence processing behavior to add ECT entries for cert path keys. A straight forward approach is the subjectPublicKeyInfo of the Issuer is placed in the ECT `authority` field and the subjectPublicKeyInfo of the Subject is placed in the `ECT.environment-map.instance-id` field. The `claims-list` portion need not be populated.

A conditional endorsement that matches on instance-id can now add to `claims-list` subsequently.

A risk of automated behavior that inserts instance identifiers is if an entity wants to manage privacy by NOT populating instance-id / other instance identifiers, the automation becomes a hurdle that must be overcome.

pulls.title: Clarify which keys are present in ECT authority field
pulls.author: andrew-draper
pulls.body: Text to answer issue #5. This text sets the authority field to include global keys at/near the top of the certificate chain.

comments.body:
Does this spec assume the transformation is applied by the Verifier?
CoRIM doesn't mandate a particular crypto-key-type-choice varient. The Evidence and Reference Value author(s) have to agree on which format will be used. This requirement would have the affect of requiring RV providers to use COSE_Key. 
If the verifier does the format translation to COSE_Key, then it doesn't matter what format is used, the Verifier will anyway convert to whatever internal format it implements. This spec doesn't define an internal representation, hence the CoRIM spec would have to define COSE_Key as the internal representation and this spec would need to be compatible that CoRIM normative.

I don't think this text is clear. All keys are global if they are secure. A key that exists on a device is device specific. If this simply references the sec-authority section wouldn't that be sufficient?

```suggestion
Having each authority in a certificate path in the ECT `authority` field lets conditional endorsement conditions  match multiple authorities within the same certificate path or match an authority that is scoped more broadly than the immediate signer of the Evidence artifact.
```
certificate path -> certification path (or the deprecated term certificate chain)
In general, COSE_Key is a good choice, but as Ned said, the actual internal representation is nor prescribed and CoRIM does not prescribe COSE_Key in its current form.
Not sure what examples of directly or indirectly are.
what was to problem to be prevented here by excluding "device-specific keys"?

[https://ietf-rats-wg.github.io/draft-ietf-rats-corim/draft-ietf-rats-corim.html#section-8.5.3](url) contains this text:

> When comparing two $crypto-key-type-choice fields for equality, a Verifier SHALL treat them as equal if their deterministic CBOR encoding is binary equal.

When we discussed that text, there was a general desire to simplify the Verifier matching algorithm by saying that they don't need to do format comparisons.

I see the following options for making life easy for CoRIM authors:
1. Prefer a particular format when inserting data into the evidence. Verifier will need to transform to that format during evidence import.
2. Hope that all Verifiers will pick the same representation during evidence import and have the CoRIM author pick the format which their Verifier used
3. Change the CoRIM spec to let verifiers perform certain supported transforms when matching authorities
I chose option 1 but I think the other options could be made to work.

With option 1 as currently written, I don't think the CoRIM spec needs to mandate any transforms. Option 2 essentially requires transforms as otherwise it won't work when the evidence import in the verifier guesses incorrectly.

I really don't like 2. I don't really have a preference for 1 or 3 - both require that the verifier does transforms, but at different points in the verification. I think 1 is simpler.

What I mean by a global key is one which is not device-specific.

The reason I suggest omitting device-specific keys is because they aren't that useful for authority matches. DICE keys below the DeviceID key are random and device specific, so a CoRIM author can't match against them unless they have already seen that device with those measurements.

So not really a problem, but reduces work.

```suggestion
The keys provided in the ECT.`authority` field SHOULD include the DeviceID key which authorized the SPDM MEASUREMENTS response carrying the Evidence as described in {{sec-authority}}, and keys which authorized the DeviceID key.
```

I don't think there is a restriction on the multiple authorities being in the same certificate path. A SPDM responder may return multiple certificate chains to multiple authorities, and it would also be ok for a conditional endorser to match against the root of multiple chains.
```suggestion
Having each authority in a certificate path in the ECT `authority` field lets conditional endorsement conditions match multiple authorities or match an authority that is scoped more broadly than the immediate signer of the Evidence artifact.
```
I am trying to distinguish between the signer of SPDM evidence, or the signer of a certificate which authorized a key which signed the SPDM evidence. I am sure this could be tightened up.

```suggestion
Each signer authority MUST be expressed using the COSE_Key varient of `$crypto-key-type-choice`.
```

> what was to problem to be prevented here by excluding "device-specific keys"?

One of the primary goals of the Verifier is to keep track of who (key) said what. If we omit the key that actually said the claim, then it seems a basic promise of the Verifier is not achieved. If we include other keys that are transitively related to the "who" key, then we're allowing more context in terms of the who. Not a problem unless there's a privacy consideration. 

A lose end thought is given an `authority` has multiple members, it is less clear which key signed Evidence, and which key signed which cert which cert in the cert path. That context gets stripped as part of building the ECT. Is that ok? I suppose its possible to reconstruct the cert path based on the keys and application of a path building routine. 

From the perspective of a conditional endorsement, only the keys that are known to outside world are useful for constructing conditions. But there's no downside to keeping the others around except for added  resource footprint. I don't know if the spec can predict what defines "outside" since in cases like TEEs the TEE key is what's relevant but it may be dynamically created. However, there is an orchestrator that dynamically updates workload status too.

The normative should say that the key that directly signed the claim MUST be included, and the keys in the cert path to the root CA SHOULD be included.

> In general, COSE_Key is a good choice, but as Ned said, the actual internal representation is nor prescribed and CoRIM does not prescribe COSE_Key in its current form.

Unlike cases where `crypto-key-type-choice` is exposed as part of an external representation, the cert path keys are in whatever representation was used when certs were minted (e.g., ber). Since there isn't a crypto-key-type-choice for DER the verifier has to convert it to something or we should add DER to the list of possible formats. CoRIM policy is to let the author of the external representation pick. But that doesn't work here. However, if we pick COSE_Key there will be implementations using PQC that can't accommodate large key structures. Maybe they will want to use a keyid/fingerprint approach.  I don't think there is universal enough adoption of COSE that all implementations will agree to it. The CoRIM internal representation is only a suggestion, so justifying COSE based on the assumption that the intrep is CBOR won't hold up. My choice is option 4, which is add DER as a crypto-key-type-choice, and then document using DER (which is just a copy operation). It is still possible for implementations to do key translation as a way to improve robustness. But that seems pragmatically out of scope for CoRIM / evidence translation drafts at this point.

I think your option 4 is similar to option 2, but with a slightly different format.

I can change this line to remove the preference, and put that into an issue if that gets this moving.

```suggestion
Each signer identity MUST be expressed using `$crypto-key-type-choice`.
```

For DICE/SPDM I don't think the Alias key (which signs the SPDM evidence) is very useful, but it is harmless to recommend that it be added.

```suggestion
The keys provided in the ECT.`authority` field SHOULD include the key which signed the SPDM MEASUREMENTS response carrying the Evidence as described in {{sec-authority}}, the DeviceID key which authorized that key and keys which authorized the DeviceID key.```

reviews.author: nedmsmith
